citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
The facility failed to provide proper equipment or services to ensure adequate veterinary care. After communication with
the attending veterinarian, during a site visit on 5/29/2024, he was unable to administer veterinary care due to the lack of
operational equipment or services that allow the veterinary team to safely and effectively isolate or restrain certain
species. Access to properly functioning equipment and appropriate facilities is necessary for diagnosing, treating and
maintaining the health of the animals. The facility shall establish and maintain programs of adequate veterinary care that
includes the availability of appropriate facilities, personnel, equipment, and services.

One side of the perimeter fence does not meet the height requirement of 6 feet. Inadequate perimeter fences can allow
predators and other animals or unauthorized people into the facility, which can unnecessarily endanger the animals in the
collection. Additionally, the fence does not serve as a secondary containment, and animals may be able to breach the
perimeter of the facility and become harmed or injured. Correct by ensuring the perimeter fence is constructed at a
minimum of 6 feet in height so that it protects animals in the facility by restricting animals and unauthorized persons from
going through or under it and so that it can function as a secondary containment system.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by 9/24/2024 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee and
must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
n
